docs.title: Satellite Re-entry Visualisation Demo (temp for 1D)
docs.text:
This module demonstrates a simple 1D satellite de-orbit simulation and visualisation workflow.

test

docs.title: Module Structure
docs.text:
• vis_test.py — Temporary test script. Runs the simulator, saves output, and calls the visualiser module.

  • visualiser.py — Contains reusable plotting functions for:

  • Altitude vs. Time (with optional noisy measurements)
  • Velocity vs. Time
  • Trajectory (x vs y)

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
1. Simulates satellite de-orbit using basic physics:
  2. Gravity and atmospheric drag
  3. Altitude-based air density
  4. Applies Gaussian noise to simulate radar altitude measurements
  5. Saves results to a .npz file (sim_output.npz)
  6. Visualises:
  7. Altitude decay with/without noise
  8. Horizontal and vertical velocities over time
  9. Descent trajectory

docs.title: Sample Outputs
docs.text:
• Altitude drops from ~120 km to 0 m
  • Velocity changes due to air drag
  • Noisy radar measurements show uncertainty in real-world conditions

docs.title: ▶️ How to Run
docs.text:
Ensure you have Python 3 and required packages:

pip install numpy scipy matplotlib

Then run:

python vis_test.py

This will: - Execute the simulation - Save results to sim_output.npz - Automatically display visual plots

docs.title: Example Plots
docs.text: Plots are rendered with matplotlib and show: - True vs. measured altitude - Velocity profiles - Descent path

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• This is based on a 1D flat-Earth simplification
  • Intended for use as an early-stage simulator for larger orbital tracking projects
  • Code is modular and ready to be extended with more physics (2D/3D, non-linear dynamics, EKF etc.)
